Hello world. Course Beginner'
Petr van Blokland The most basic website in Xierpa3: Hello world. How to build the most simple website in Xierpa3: Hello world.

chapter.lead: This example instruction shows coding of the most simple website in Xierpa3: Hello world. Stay close for our first walk-through.
chapter.p: Open a new Python code document, in an editor suitable for programming, such as BBEdit, TextWrangler, Coda, or any other applications that understands Python syntax. Add this first line to the document, to indicate that it may contain UTF-8 (Unicode) strings.
Then we will define the Xierpa3 component and builder classes that we need in our website page.
chapter.code: from xierpa3.components import Theme, Page, Column from xierpa3.builders.cssbuilder import CssBuilder from xierpa3.builders.htmlbuilder import HtmlBuilder
chapter.p: From the set of available Xierpa3 components, the Theme is used, as site container for the single Page. On the page there will be one Column.

Next is to define the type of column we want to have, holding the simple “Hello world” text. We create a new type of component for this behavior, which initially inherits all aspect from the standard Column class.

The b.div instructs the HTML builder to build an HTML open div tag, where the b.div creates a closing tag. The CSS builder generates the corresponding CSS codes for this div, taking the color attribute as value. This attribute is ignored by the HTML builder. Builders know which attributes are for them.

Now we defined our new type of component, we need a page to place it on. Create a new type of theme, that initially inherits all behavior from the main Xierpa3 Theme component. TITLE defines the specific page name for this type of theme, that will appear on the top of the browser window.
chapter.code: class HelloWorld(Theme): TITLE = u'The standard “Hello world” page.'
chapter.p: Then one of the required methods is defined for a Theme, answering the list of Page instances, each filled with their set of components. In this case there only a one home page, which contains one element: the instance of HelloWorldText.
chapter.code: def baseComponents(self): hw = HelloWorldText() homePage = Page(components=(hw,), title=self.TITLE) return [homePage]
chapter.p: Calling the self.make() method will build the CSS and HTML and place the result in a directory on the users’ desktop. This index.html can be dragged on a browser to view. The CSS is saved in a local css directory.
In the next example, we’ll add some more styling and layout to the page. Again we import the required classes from Xierpa.
chapter.code: from xierpa3.components import Theme, Page, Column from xierpa3.builders.cssbuilder import CssBuilder from xierpa3.builders.htmlbuilder import HtmlBuilder from xierpa3.constants.constants import C from xierpa3.attributes import Em, Margin
chapter.p: And again we create a new component, that inherits all behavior from the existing Column class. The C class contains a number of constants that can be used throughout the code, to make sure that there is not misspelling in names and types. The use of attribute instances such as Em and Margin in the example shows the principle of storing knowsledge into attribute instances. Shadow and Gradient (shown in other example site) are also attributes that hide complex HTML and CSS from the development level of the user.
chapter.code: class HelloWorldText(Column): def buildBlock(self, b): b.div(class_='column', color='yellow', margin=Margin(0, C.AUTO, 0, C.AUTO), width='70%', maxwidth=700, minwidth=300, backgroundcolor='#222', padding=Em(0.5), fontfamily='Georgia', fontsize=Em(4), textalign=C.CENTER, lineheight=Em(1.4)) b.text('Hello world.') b._div() b.div(class_='caption', color='#888', margin=Margin(0, C.AUTO, 0, C.AUTO), width='70%', maxwidth=700, minwidth=300, paddingleft=Em(0.5), fontfamily='Georgia', fontsize=Em(0.8), textalign=C.CENTER, lineheight=Em(1.4), fontstyle=C.ITALIC) b.text('Generated by Xierpa3.') b._div()
chapter.p: Note that although the div may suggest that it is just HTML building there, the method get called both with b as CssBuilder and as HtmlBuilder. Each builder will filter out the appropriate attributes and translates it into its own syntax. The HTML tags generated by the article are set in CSS by the empty statements.
Building the styled 2 text blocks, written out with duplicated values, as example how this works. See other examples for approaches with more cascading styled hierarchy.

Also note that for clarity of the example, the two div blocks have their own (redundant) styling. In a real site application these values would come from the same source, defining their relation in Python code. Also these values will be translated into SASS variables, which can be altered there, if the generated files are to be used again for manual manipulation, such as external templates. The rest of this example is the identical to the simple HelloWorld.
